data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

docs.text: Jane exchanged 500 Singapore dollars ($) into Thai baht (THB) when the exchange rate was $1 = 26.77 THB. She travelled to Thailand and spent 10,600 THB. Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output:
During a carnival event, the entrance fees are $85 for adults, $55 for teenagers, and $30 for children. On Saturday, the event had 350 adults, 420 teenagers, and 190 children attending, while on Sunday, they had 370 adults, 405 teenagers, and 210 children. The attendance for Saturday and Sunday can be modeled by the matrix \( A = \begin{pmatrix} 350 & 420 & 190 \\ 370 & 405 & 210 \end{pmatrix} \). 

(i) Construct a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( F \), that represents the entrance fees for adults, teenagers, and children. 

(ii) Compute the matrix \( C = AF \). 

(iii) Interpret what each of the elements in matrix \( C \) signifies. 

(iv) Determine the total revenue generated from ticket sales over the two days.

A local theme park sells three types of tickets: regular, premium, and VIP. The regular ticket is priced at $45, the premium at $60, and the VIP at $85. On Saturday, 180 regular, 220 premium, and 30 VIP tickets were sold, while on Sunday, 200 regular, 250 premium, and 25 VIP tickets were sold. 

(i) Write a 3x1 matrix, T, to represent the price of the tickets. 
(ii) Let matrix S represent the ticket sales over Saturday and Sunday as \( S = \begin{pmatrix} 180 & 220 & 30 \\ 200 & 250 & 25 \end{pmatrix} \). Find the matrix P = ST. 
(iii) Interpret what each element of matrix P represents. 
(iv) Calculate the total revenue collected from these two days.
